citation.article-title: Leuconostoc ficulneum sp. nov., a novel lactic acid bacterium isolated from a ripe fig, and reclassification of Lactobacillus fructosus as Leuconostoc fructosum comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Leuconostoc ficulneum sp. nov.
Leuconostoc ficulneum (fi.cul'ne.um. L. adj. ficulneum pertaining to figs and fig trees)
Short, rod-shaped cells, 0.4-1.0 μm in width by 1.8- 2.9 μm in length.
The Gram stain is positive; cells are not motile and spores are not formed.
Colonies are small, smooth, round and grey-white.
The optimum temperature for growth is approximately 30 °C; no growth occurs at 6 or 40 °C.
The optimum pH is between 6.5 and 7.0; no growth occurs at pH 4.5.
The maximum NaCl concentration for growth is 7.0% and the maximum glucose concentration for growth is 40%.
The cell-wall murein is type A3α, variation L-Lys←L-Ala.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are hexadecanoic acid (16:0) and 11,12-octadecenoic acid (18:1 Δ11, 18:1ω7c).
Catalase activity is present but cytochrome oxidase is not.
Arginine dehydrolase is absent.
Does not hydrolyse elastin, fibrin, gelatin, casein, starch or aesculin.
Does not produce dextran from sucrose.
Heterofermentative; a small amount of fructose (5%) is fermented via the Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas pathway.
The major fermentation products of fructose are mannitol, lactate and acetate.
The lactate isomer is D(-).

Acid is produced from D-glucose and D-fructose in API 50CHL microtubes, the production of acid from gluconate, mannitol and trehalose is delayed and the fermentation of sucrose and D-turanose is weak.
Acid is not produced from other carbohydrates tested (Table 1).
The G+C content of the DNA of strain FS-1T is 42.6 mol% (as determined by the HPLC method).
The type strain, FS-1T (=DSM 13613T=NRRL B-23447T), was isolated from a ripe fig bought in Portugal.
